statement.text: Compression therapy is the cornerstone of lymphedema management, utilizing short-stretch bandages during reduction phase and fitted compression garments for maintenance, applying external pressure to reduce edema, enhance lymphatic flow, and prevent refilling.

explanation.intuition: Compression works like squeezing a sponge during activity - when muscles contract against the external bandage, pressure rises dramatically to push fluid out. At rest, pressure drops to allow comfort. This on-off pumping enhances lymphatic and venous return.
explanation.key_insight: Short-stretch bandages are preferred over long-stretch elastic bandages because they provide high 'working pressure' during muscle activity (when you want to push fluid) but low 'resting pressure' at rest (for comfort and to avoid arterial compromise).
explanation.technical_details: Short-stretch bandages have extensibility <100% (typically 40-70%) providing a semi-rigid shell. With muscle contraction, intra-compartmental pressure rises substantially against this inelastic material. Laplace's Law governs pressure: P = nT/CW (n=layers, T=tension, C=circumference, W=width). Graduated compression higher distally creates pressure gradient driving proximal flow. Working pressure with short-stretch: 60-80 mmHg during activity; resting pressure: 20-30 mmHg. Compression garments (Class II: 20-30 mmHg; Class III: 30-40 mmHg; Class IV: 40-50 mmHg) maintain reduction. Custom flat-knit garments for irregular shapes; circular-knit for regular contours.

mechanisms.muscle_pump: Semi-rigid shell amplifies muscle pump effect
mechanisms.tissue_stiffness: Limits further swelling, reduces protein extravasation

bandaging.padding: Cotton stockinette + foam padding for even pressure distribution
bandaging.technique: Spiral or figure-8 from digits to proximal limb

construction.circular_knit: Seamless, more comfortable, for regular limb shapes
construction.flat_knit: Custom seamed, stiffer, for irregular shapes, severe cases

special_considerations.night_compression: Lower pressure wraps or specialized night garments for severe cases
special_considerations.adjustable_wraps: Velcro systems for patients unable to don garments
special_considerations.pneumatic_compression: Intermittent pneumatic devices as adjunct therapy

contraindications.CHF: Decompensated heart failure (rapid fluid mobilization risk)

definition.@value: The application of external pressure through bandages or garments to reduce lymphedema, enhance lymphatic flow, and maintain treatment gains through graduated compression.

sources.title: Handbook of Venous and Lymphatic Disorders

learning_objectives: Explain the mechanisms of compression therapy
Select appropriate compression class for patient needs
clinical_pearls: SHORT-stretch bandages = HIGH working pressure, LOW resting pressure
Long-stretch elastic bandages are WRONG for lymphedema (sustained high pressure)
Garments must be replaced every 4-6 months as they lose elasticity
Flat-knit custom garments for irregular limb shapes or severe cases
Always check ABI before compression - arterial disease is a contraindication
Night compression (low pressure) helps severe cases maintain gains
